speaker: Doctor
text: I've reviewed your chart, but I'd like to start from the beginning. Can you tell me, when did you first start experiencing symptoms of persistent vomiting and chest pain?

speaker: Patient
text: "It started last night, after I had a few too many drinks. I remember feeling okay at first, but then I just couldn't stop vomiting. The pain in my chest came later, after I was retching really hard."

speaker: Doctor
text: It started about a week ago, I'd say. The vomiting was pretty mild at first, but it's been getting worse and the chest pain has been constant.

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been getting worse and worse, and now it's like I'm choking on my own vomit. I can feel it going down my throat, but I just can't get it out."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any weight loss since the symptoms started, and are you taking any medications for your symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: "I haven't really been able to eat much since it started, so I guess I have lost some weight. I'm not really sure how much, but I feel like I'm wasting away. As for medication, I've been taking something my friend gave me, but I don't think it's really helping."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've noticed you seem a bit anxious, is everything okay? Are you experiencing any difficulty breathing or shortness of breath along with the chest pain?

speaker: Patient
text: "I'm just really scared, to be honest. It feels like my throat is closing up and I'm running out of air. Every time I try to cough, it feels like my lungs are burning."

speaker: Doctor
text: Are you experiencing any pain or discomfort in your abdomen, specifically around your stomach or intestines?

speaker: Patient
text: "Uh, yeah, it feels like my stomach is just churning nonstop. Every time I try to vomit, it feels like it's going to rip my insides apart. The pain is right below my ribcage, and it's constant."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've noticed that your pulse is a bit rapid and your blood pressure is slightly elevated. Can you tell me if you've had any recent travel or exposure to anyone with a similar illness?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't think so. I've just been stuck at home, trying to recover from... everything. I did recently get treated for Lyme disease, though. Does that have anything to do with it?"

speaker: Doctor
text: You mentioned that the vomiting was mild at first but has been getting worse. Have you noticed any blood in your vomit or stools?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's just been getting darker and darker, like coffee grounds. And the pain in my chest, it feels like it's getting tighter, like something is squeezing my heart."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your symptoms and exam results. I'd like to ask: Have you experienced any difficulty swallowing or regurgitation of food since the symptoms started?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, yeah, it's like food is getting stuck in my throat. Sometimes I try to swallow and it feels like it's just going to come back up. I've been eating really small amounts, but even that's been a struggle."

speaker: Doctor
text: You've had a few episodes of difficulty swallowing, but it's not a constant issue. It usually happens when you're eating or drinking something cold.

speaker: Patient
text: "Ugh, yeah, it's not just cold things. Sometimes it's just like my throat is closing up, no matter what I'm eating or drinking. And when it happens, it feels like I'm going to choke."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your bowel movements since the symptoms started, such as diarrhea or constipation?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been more like... I don't know, it's hard to explain. Everything just feels like it's moving really fast, like my stomach is just racing. Sometimes I feel like I'm going to lose control, you know? And the pain, it's just... ugh."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any fever or chills since the symptoms started, and do you have a history of any underlying medical conditions, such as heart disease or liver disease?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've had a few episodes of feeling really hot, like my body is on fire. And yeah, I have a history of drinking, but I don't think that's the problem here. I've been trying to cut back, but it's hard when it feels like my body is just rebelling against me."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your recent bowel movements, but I'd like to ask: Have you experienced any pain or discomfort in your back, specifically in the middle or upper back, since the symptoms started?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, yeah, it feels like someone is stabbing me in the middle of my back. It's a sharp, stabbing pain that radiates down to my chest. It's been getting worse with each episode of vomiting and coughing."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've noticed that your symptoms seem to be worsening over time, which is concerning. Have you experienced any nausea or dizziness since the symptoms started?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, yeah, all the time. I feel like I'm going to pass out every time I stand up. The room just spins and I get this wave of nausea that makes me want to vomit even more. It's like my body is just trying to shut down on me."

speaker: Doctor
text: I see that your symptoms have been progressing, and that's not a good sign. Have you experienced any difficulty lying flat or do you feel more comfortable sitting up?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, I feel a lot better when I'm sitting up. Lying down just makes me feel like I'm going to choke even more. Every time I try to lie flat, I get this tightness in my chest and my throat starts to close up. Sitting up seems to help, but it's not like I can just relax or anything."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to ask, have you experienced any numbness or tingling sensations in your arms or legs since the symptoms started?

speaker: Patient
text:
"Uh, yeah, my hands have been feeling really numb and tingly. It's like pins and needles, but it doesn't go away. Sometimes it's just my fingers, but other times it's my whole arm. It's really uncomfortable and makes it hard to do even simple things like button my shirt."

Are you able to move your arms and legs freely, or are they stiff or weak?

speaker: Doctor
text: I've asked you 15 questions so far, let me summarize what we have. Can you confirm that the vomiting has been getting worse, and you haven't experienced any relief from it?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, it's been getting worse every day. I haven't been able to keep anything down, and it feels like I'm going to vomit all the time. Even thinking about eating or drinking makes me feel like I'm going to throw up."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to confirm that the vomiting has indeed been getting worse and you haven't experienced any relief from it. That's very concerning. Have you noticed any difficulty speaking or slurring your words since the symptoms started?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's getting harder to talk, to be honest. Sometimes my words get all jumbled up and I have to take a few deep breaths before I can speak clearly. It's like my throat is trying to close up on me, but I'm fighting it."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any difficulty swallowing or choking on food since the symptoms started, especially when eating or drinking?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, yeah, it's like I said before, food gets stuck in my throat and I feel like I'm going to choke. Sometimes it happens when I'm eating, but other times it's when I'm drinking something, even just water. It's like my airway is getting narrower and narrower, and I'm running out of room to breathe."

speaker: Doctor
text: You mentioned you experienced difficulty swallowing when eating or drinking something cold, but it's not constant. Can you tell me if the difficulty swallowing is more severe when you're eating hot foods or liquids?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's not just hot foods or liquids, doctor. It's like my throat is just getting tighter and tighter, no matter what I'm eating or drinking. Sometimes I feel like I'm going to aspirate, like food or liquid is going to go into my lungs instead of down my throat. It's really scary."

speaker: Doctor
text:
I have to say, I'm concerned about the progression of your symptoms and the fact that you haven't experienced any relief from the vomiting. I'm going to take a deep breath and try to piece together everything we've discussed. 

Before I make a diagnosis, I do want to request one more test: REQUEST TEST: ECG.
